questions.question_text:
In an Object Storage bucket you have two objects named ObjectA and ObjectB. ObjectA was last modified six months ago and ObjectB was modified 14 months ago. You create a retention rule and specify a duration of 1 year.
What does the rule do?

choices.B: It prevents the modification or deletion of ObjectA for the next 6 months and prevents the modification or deletion of ObjectB for the next 2 months.
choices.D: It prevents the modification or deletion of ObjectA and ObjectB for the next 12 months.
choices.A: It prevents the modification or deletion of ObjectA for the next 6 months and allows the modification or deletion of ObjectB.
choices.C: It prevents the modification or deletion of ObjectA for the next 12 months and prevents the modification or deletion of ObjectB for the next 14 months.
Allow group A-Admins to manage all-resources in compartment Project-A
choices.B: Allow any-user to inspect users in tenancy
choices.D: Allow group A-Developers to create volumes in compartment Project-A
choices.A: Allow dynamic-group FrontEnd to manage instance-family in compartment Project-A

questions.question_text: Which Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) Identity and Access Management (IAM) policy is invalid?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
confirmed via documentation C

Selected Answer: B
confirmed via documentation B

Selected Answer: D
I will go for D. Allow group A-Developers to create volumes in compartment Project-A

Selected Answer: B
Among the provided Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) Identity and Access Management (IAM) policies, option B is invalid:

B. Allow any-user to inspect users in tenancy

This policy is invalid because "any-user" is not a valid identity or group in OCI IAM. You must specify a valid IAM group or user when defining policies, and "any-user" is not a recognized identity. IAM policies should be associated with specific groups or users to grant them permissions.

The other options (A, C, and D) are valid IAM policies as they follow the correct format and use valid IAM entities (groups, compartments, etc.) in their definitions.

To specify any user in the tenancy:
Allow any-user to inspect users in tenancy
I agree with 93f75c4

There is no policy on Create-Volumes

B. Burstable instances are designed for scenarios where an instance is not typically idle and has high CPU utilization. -- should be LOW CPU Utilization
D. Baseline utilization is a fraction of each CPU core, either 25% or 75%. -- The baseline utilization is a fraction of each CPU core, either 12.5% or 50%

Selected Answer: BD
B and D : Burstable instances are designed for scenarios where an instance "is typically" idle or has low CPU utilization with occasional spikes in usage. and The baseline utilization is a fraction of each CPU core, either "12.5% or 50%". Refer to this link: https://docs.oracle.com/en-us/iaas/Content/Compute/References/burstable-instances.htm

questions.question_text: Which TWO statements are NOT correct regarding the Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) burstable instances? (Choose two.)

choices.A: Burstable instances cost less than regular instances with the same total OCPU count.
choices.B: Burstable instances are designed for scenarios where an instance is not typically idle and has high CPU utilization.
choices.D: Baseline utilization is a fraction of each CPU core, either 25% or 75%.
choices.C: If the instance's average CPU utilization over the past 24 hours is below the baseline, the system allows it to burst above the baseline.
choices.E: Burstable instances are charged according to the baseline OCPU.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AE
A. Cloud Agent Plugin: Oracle Cloud Agent is used to collect logs and metrics from on-premises environments and send them to OCI Logging service. The Cloud Agent Plugin is a component of Oracle Cloud Agent that can be configured to collect logs from specific sources and send them to the OCI Logging service.

E. Object Collection Rule: Object Collection Rules are used to define what logs or log entries should be collected and sent to OCI Logging service. You can create an Object Collection Rule that specifies the criteria for collecting Info-level logging data from your on-premises instances and then forwarding it to the OCI Logging service.

Selected Answer: AE
Cloud Agent Plugin: The Cloud Agent Plugin can be used to collect logs from on-premises instances and send them to OCI Logging.
ObjectCollection Rule: An ObjectCollection Rule can be used to archive Info-level logging data from OCI Logging to OCI Object Storage.

Grouping Function: The Grouping Function is used to group log data into logical groups. This can be useful for filtering and analyzing log data.
Agent Configuration: Agent Configuration is used to configure the Cloud Agent Plugin.
Service Connectors: Service Connectors are used to collect logs from OCI services and send them to OCI Logging

Selected Answer: AE
To achieve the requirement of archiving Info-level logging data from on-premises instances into OCI Object Storage, you can use the following two features of OCI:

A. Cloud Agent Plugin:

 Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) Logging provides the Cloud Agent Plugin, which allows you to collect logs from on-premises environments and send them to OCI Logging. You can configure the Cloud Agent Plugin on your on-premises instances to collect and forward logs to OCI Logging.

E. ObjectCollection Rule:

 In OCI Logging, ObjectCollection Rules are used to specify which log data should be archived to OCI Object Storage. You can define rules to filter and select Info-level logging data and then configure these rules to archive the selected logs to OCI Object Storage.

So, the correct options are A. Cloud Agent Plugin and E. ObjectCollection Rule.

Selected Answer: CD
C. Agent Configuration: You can configure OCI Logging agents on your on-premises instances to collect and send logs to the OCI Logging service. You can specify the log levels and types you want to collect, including Info-level logs.

D. Service Connectors: OCI Logging service supports service connectors, which allow you to archive logs to external destinations, including OCI Object Storage. You can configure service connectors to route logs to the desired storage locations, and in this case, you can set up a connector to archive Info-level logs to OCI Object Storage.

Custom logs are ingested by installing Fluentd Agent on the on-premises system along with setting up the Agent Configuration in the Logging service. Service Connectors are used to transition logs from Logging service to other OCI services. To archive logs into Object Storage, Service Connector could be configured.
Agent Configuration and Service Connector are correct
AD OPTION ARE CORRECT

Selected Answer: CD
I would say correct Answer is ACD but we we need to choose 2 then CD. Because C (Agent Configration) will include installation of A (plugin) into on-primises boxes.

Selected Answer: CD
Agent Configuration and Service COnnector
Should be agent configuration and service connector

questions.question_text:
You are part of a team that manages a set of workload instances running in an on-premises environment. The Architect team is tasked with designing and configuring Oracle Cloud Infrastructure (OCI) Logging service to collect logs from these instances. There is a requirement to archive Info-level logging data of these instances into the OCI Object Storage.
Which TWO features of OCI can help you achieve this? (Choose two.)

You are launching a new project in the US West (Phoenix) region. You would like to reserve the compute capacity mentioned below so that the capacity is available for your workloads when you need it.
10 VM.Standard2.2 Instances
6 VM.Standard.E4.Flex Instances
The project also requires you to be mindful about high availability and place the instances in at least two Availability Domains.
At a bare minimum, how many capacity reservations would you create to meet this requirement?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
confirmed via documentation B

Selected Answer: B
confirmed via documentation B

Selected Answer: C
The correct answer is C (two). One per availability domain.
